CREDIT AND PROJECT SUMMARY
Recipient: Republic of Iraq
Beneficiary: Road Users throughout Iraq
ImplementingAgencies: State Commission for Roads and Bridges (SCRB), (Ministry of Construction and Housing); and General Directorate of Roads and Bridges (KRG-GDRB), (Ministry o f Construction and Housing, Kurdistan Regional Government).
Credit: IDA Emergency Recovery Credit
Amount & Terms: SDR 93.2 million (US$135.0 million equivalent); 35-year term with a ten-year grace period.
Objectives & Description: The objective of the proposed Emergency Road Rehabilitation Project is to improve the condition of road assets by rehabilitating highly damaged segments of the country's highway and rural road networks, reestablishing critical river crossings, and restoring the capacity to manage and maintain road assets.
Benefits and Risks: Benefits: The project will benefit road users throughout Iraq, as well as promote the country's economic integration, facilitate trade, and support reconstruction efforts across all sectors. Although the project i s essentially an emergency operation, substantial benefits would be derived from attempts to address medium- to long-term policy and institutional issues, and by developing a vision for how road sector assets should be managed and developed beyond the emergency stage. The civil works and subsequent maintenance activities will also provide local employment opportunities. Risks: The project will be implemented in a high risk environment. The unstable security situation and limited capacity o f the private sector and government counterparts pose the greatest risks. Contractors and consultants working in Iraq will face high risks, and special arrangements may be needed to ensure a reasonable level of protection. A presentation o f risks, including proposed measures to mitigate their impact, is provided in Paragraph32.
ProjectAppraisal Document: This Project has been prepared in accordance with Emergency Recovery Assistance procedures (Operational Policy 8.50). As such, this Technical Annex provides the information normally available in a Project Appraisal Document.
Disbursement: The Project is expected to be completed by December 31, 2009. The Credit's closing date is June 30, 2010.

Country Background
1. Large oil reserves and abundant natural and human resources enabled Iraq to attain the status o f a middle-income country in the 1970s. Years o f conflict, misdirected resources, and the effects o f Iraq's centralized command economy stifled economic growth and development, prevented the proper maintenance o f basic infrastructure, and negatively impacted social services. More recent conflicts have resulted in looting and sabotage with direct damage to buildings, pipelines, and transportation and communication links. As a result, Iraq's human development indicators are now among the lowest inthe region. According to 2004 estimates, Gross Domestic Product (GDP) stood at US$942 per person, and at least two million Iraqis were unemployed, a figure that represents about 30 percent o f the overall workforce. Access to basic services, such as power, water, affordable transportation, healthcare, and education, are inadequate; and income inequality, which i s growing, may exacerbate social tensions. On- going insecurity further increases poverty and vulnerability, while poor or unreliable access to work and employment opportunities, markets and social services i s causing temporary hardship for a large segment of the population, and could lead to increased long-term, chronic poverty.
International Response
2. At the request of the international community, the World Bank and the United Nations Development Group produced a joint United NationsiWorld Bank Iraq Needs Assessment in October 2003. The assessment estimated total reconstruction needs at US$35.8 billion, excluding oil and security expenditures. The report served as the basis for an international Donor Conference inMadrid in October 2003. Of the nearly USfi32.0 billion pledged by donors at the conference, most was earmarked for bilateral distribution. The United States (US) was the single largest contributor to Iraq's reconstruction effort, and most o f the USS18.6 billion approved by the US Congress was for infrastructure.' Japan, the second largest contributor, allocated about US$5.0 billion, largely for electricity, and water supply and sanitation. Other major pledges came from the United Kingdom, Italy, the European Commission, Spain and Canada, which together pledgedabout U S 3 . 0 billion.

Road Sector Background
4. Once regarded as having one o f the Middle East's most comprehensive transportation systems, Iraq's transport infrastructure has suffered from more than two decades of neglect and underinvestment. Between 1980 and 2003, regional conflicts, the utilization o f public resources to support military initiatives, an extended period o f economic sanctions, and deferred maintenance contributed to a pernicious and general decline in the quality o f transport facilities and services, and to huge losses in rolling stock. With the onset o f the 2003 military intervention, many assets were damaged due to heavy bombing, while the looting that followed stripped ministries and transport facilities o f equipment, machinery, furniture and supplies. In addition to these challenges, Iraq must transition from a centrally- planned, command economy to one that is market based. 5. Iraq's 42,000 hlorneter road network is classified as national highways, primary roads, secondary roads, village access roads and special purpose roads (military and border roads). Although some 85 percent o f the network i s paved, damages sustained during numerous conflicts, inadequate repairs, and deferred maintenance have rendered much o f the network to fair or poor condition`. As a result, a large share o f roads i s in immediate need o f rehabilitation. There has also been a pronounced deterioration of village access roads, which has diminished access to markets and social services in many rural areas. The topography o f Iraq, with two inajor river systems along which most cities are located, makes bridges a vital part o f the road network. As a result o f the first Gulf War and subsequent conflicts, many o f the country's more than 1,000 bridges suffered damage, and several key river crossings were never provided withreplacementbridges. Instead, temporaiy structures (floatingbridges)were put inplace.
6. With the exception o f municipal roads, responsibility for constructing and maintaining the classified road network lies with the Ministry o f Construction and Housing (MOCH), and specifically, the State Commission for Roads and Bridges (SCRB). However, policy formulation and planning activities for the road sector are the responsibilities of the Ministry o f Planning and Development Cooperation (MOPDC). Local roads in cities and towns under the jurisdiction o fmunicipalities are the responsibility of the Ministry o f Municipalities and Public Works (MMPW). In the northern Governorates, there i s a regional Ministry o f Construction and Housing and a General Directorate o f Roads (GDRB) that mirror the structure of, and have similar responsibilities as, the M O C H and the SCRB. This arrangement has been inplace for more than ten years.
7. The consulting industry in Iraq encompasses four types o f public and private institutions: (a) engineering offices in ministries; (b) consulting services offered by universities; (c) goveniment-owned consulting corporations; and (d) privately owned consulting firms. Inthe 1970s, there were a number o f private consulting firms in all fields o f engineering, but due to a change in policy requiring ministries to rely on in-house expertise and parastatal consulting corporations, the quality and capacity o f the private sector deteriorated to the extent that it no longer offers services in the transport sector. This i s partly because the SCRB and the GDRB have developed and relied on its in-house capacity3 to design most of the country's roads and bridges, and because the universities have been encouraged to cany out the technically more difficult studies. The main parastatal consulting corporation i s the National Center for Engineering Consultancy (NCEC), which has some capabilities in the area o froad and bridge design.Few of these institutions .have experience in undertalung independent construction supervision as the "Engineer" according to the Federation Internationale des Ingenieurs Conseils (FDIC) conditions o f contract. The Iraqi EngineeringUnion classifies engineering firms and licenses professional engineers.
8. The road construction industry in Iraq can be classified in two main categories: (a) private entrepreneurs; and (b) state-owned construction corporations. The capacity and capabilities o f the private sector has been depleted due to years o f war and increased reliance on parastatal corporations. Presently, it can only offer sub-contracting services to larger foreign companies. The Iraqi Contractors' Federation has ten classifications for contractors, but only publicly owned coi-porations are in the top categoiy. However, several have the experience and equipment to carry out works for roads, bridges, buildings and other infrastructpe, and the local consulting and contracting industries have been instrumental in past reconstruction efforts, particularly after the 1991 Gulf War. One can also expect that private sector contractors, with some facilitation and opporhmities for road and bridge works, could expand their capabilities and compete with the publicly owned corporations, as well as foreign contractors.

9. Loss ofKey Rond Assets. In a large country such as Iraq, with a total land area o f about 432,000 square Jan, and around 27 million inhabitants, roads play a central role in the movement o f people and goods. Estimates indicate that roads accommodate 70 percent o f all land transport in Iraq. Most o f the . country's nearly 42,000 km` road network was developed in the 1970s and 198Os, and little, if any, new construction has taken place since. Although some S5 percent o f the network i s paved, maintenance has consistently been deferred. As a result, large backlogs of maintenance have accumulated over the years, pavementshave failed inmany areas, and a significant portion of the network i s in need o f rehabilitation.
10. Deterioration of Village Access Roads. Inadequate repairs and maintenance have also contributed to a pronounced deterioration in village roads, which have been neglected to the extent that reconstruction, rather then rehabilitation, i s needed along much of the rural road network. This has diminishedaccess to markets and social services inmany rural areas, and contributes to isolation.
11. Bridges Critical to Iraq's Road Network. The topography of Iraq, with two major river systems along which most cities are located, make bridges a vital part o f the road network, which includes more than 1,000 bridges. As a result o f the first Gulf War, many of the country's bridges' were damaged, and several key connections were never replaced. Instead, temporary structures (floating bridges)6were put in place. Because of the sanctions, iiiost rehabilitative works were stopped and only limited maintenance activities undertaken.
12. Absence of Quality Control hfeaszires. Another key loss was the Government road laboratories, which were decimated by looting. Not only were equipment and supplies stolen, but most o f the institutional capacity at the country's central and regional facilities was also negatively impacted. These laboratories played an important role in controlling the quality o f road constniction, and need to be reconstituted on an urgent basis.
13. Weakened Capacitql to ibfanage Road Network. Historically, capacity to manage the country's network o f roads has been strong and adequate. However, reliance on outdated procedures and equipment has eroded skills and abilities, which are inneed o f updating and strengthening. The process of managing roads would also benefit froni re-engineering, including adopting modern techniques and delegating appropriate levels o f administrative and managerial autonomy to the provincial offices.
14. Rapidly Expanding VehicleFleet. In 1970, there were just 122,200 vehicles registered in Iraq. By 1980, the number had grown to 463,000, and reached one million in 1989. Under the economic sanctions o f the 199Os, growth slowed sharply, however, various sources indicate that more than 500,000' used-vehicles were imported into Iraq between mid-2003 and early 2004. This represents an increase in excess of 40 percent in Iraq's vehicle fleet inless than a year. Due to extensive reliance on land transport and demand that has been suppressed for more than a decade, the size of Iraq's vehicle fleet i s expected to continue increasing rapidly, which will cause traffic to grow significantly. Already, several key arteries linkingmajor urban centers are experiencinghightraffic volumes' andhave reached saturation.

15. Inresponseto a foniial request from theInterimGovernment inDecember2004,theWorldBank agreed to extend Iraq up to US$500 million in International Development Association (IDA) Credits between FY2005 and FY2007. This comes in addition to the funds available in the ITF. It i s expected that the Bank Group's work program will represent a range o f potential IDA interventions based on three objectives, which are to: (a) build institutional capacity, and especially to establish mechanisms o f transparency and accountability urgently needed for implementing the large amount o f external funding needed for Iraq's reconstruction; (b) prepare and implement, to the extent possible under the circumstances, emergency operations to generate employment and kick-start economic activity, and restore essential infrastructure and services; and (c) lay the groundwork for Iraq's medium-term reconstruction and development program, and begin assisting inthe transition from a centrally-planned economy to one that i s market-based through the provision o f policy advice and analytical work.
16. To date, the Bank has approved ten ITF-financed projects, one o f which has closed. Of the nine projects currently under implementation, eight are being implemented by Iraqi authorities. This i s a considerable achievement, considering that Iraq lacks recent experience with international donor procedures and has not borrowed from the Bank for 25 years.g The Bank's implementing arrangements seek to ensure Iraqi ownership and strengthen institutional capacity, which contrasts with the implementation arrangements usedby some donors.
17. The Bank also prepared a Second InterimStrategy for Iraq (discussed by the Executive Directors on September 15, 2005), which seeks to guide the development of efficient, transparent and accountable institutions as a means of supporting economic activity. The Strategy stresses the need to restore basic service delivery, and particularly to address transport bottlenecks that impede reconstruction and public access to services and markets. Within this context, the Government has asked the Bank's financial support for an Emergency Road RehabilitationProject ( E m ) .
18.- As indicated in the Bank's Second Interim Strategy Note for Iraq, Government priorities for the US$500 million IDA allocation are for education, electricity, transport and water supply. As per the Government's declaration that 17 percent o f donor support be earmarked for projects determined by the Kurdistan Regional Government (KRG), the KRG explicitly requested that its share of the US$500 million IDA allocation be concentrated in roads (US$45 million) and power (US$40 million). In November 2005, Executive Directors approved the first IDA Credit to Iraq UStSlOO million for a Third - Emergency Education Project. The proposed ERRP would be the second IDA Credit for Iraq. In June 2006, the new fiill-term Government o f Iraqreconfirmed its support for the proposed ERRP.
Rationale for Bank Involvement
19. Inresponse to the tremendous need to rehabilitate and restore basic infrastructure facilities and services throughout Iraq, initial donor support was primarily directed to finance priority investments in the power and water sectors, as well as to improve key social services. While road sector assets have not received the same level of attention, their condition has reached a critical stage where their rehabilitation, essential to the reconstruction effort, can no longer be deferred. The preservation o f road assets was identified by the Government as a priority, and support for a project to rehabilitate key segments of the network and prepare overall road rehabilitation and rural access programs was expressly requested to be part o f the first IDA allocation. The civil works and subsequent maintenance activities associated with the ERRPwill also create some muchneeded local employment opportunities inthe near-terni.

The rationale for significant IDA involvement at this stage in rehabilitating Iraq's highway and rural road infrastructure is its comparative advantage in addressing immediate needs, while at the same time strengthening the policy and institutional framework for the sector's long-term sustainability. In addition, there i s a significant financing gap in the sector in the short- to medium-term (US$2.25 billion for the transport sector, of which USO.575 billion i s earmarked for roads and bridges)." As noted above, large donors, such as the United States and Japan, are channeling most o f their suipport to other infrastructure investments, with little funding for the road sector, and there i s need for substantial additional financing to address road transport bottlenecks and other inefficiencies in the sector. The Bank has the resources, experience, and expertise to support new road sector operations, and to complement ongoing investments through the regular Iraqi budget.
21. The Bank i s in a position to share international experience and best practices based on its considerable involvement in implementing transport infrastructure projects and reestablishing capacity in conflict-affected areas. The Bank's reconstruction efforts put a premium on early, but selective engagement, flexibility in design and implementation, capacity restoration, coordination with donors and other partners, and close monitoring and evaluation.
22. Other factors are: Once operational, Bank-financed projects often attract resources from other. development agencies and Government budgets, and assist inmore efficient utilization and coordination of investments and technical assistance in the sector. In this context, an early output o f the ERRP will be to identify a road rehabilitationprogram, which can be used to seek additional fLinding from other donors. In this respect, the Islamic Development Bank has expressed interest inproviding parallel financing to rehabilitate and widen the road from Altun Kopri to Kirkuk,which would conipleinent Component B.l ofthe E W . Bank financing, in contrast to the financing offered by many other donors, would be implemented by Iraq through the country's own ministries and agencies, which would better ensure Iraqi ownership and build institutional capacity, both o f which are crucial for the country's longer-term development. In this case, the strategy would be to build on existing capacity by establishing dedicated project management teams. The project management teams are viewed as necessaiy because o f the large financing requirements, and as a means to buildcapacity. The Bank will provide financing to the Government for rehabilitative works combined with policy advice, institutional development and reform assistance, all o f which are essential for the long-term sustainability o f investments inthe road sector. Focus should also be placed on increasing harmonization with other donors and, to the extent possible, laying the foundation for longer-term engagement. With the exception o f the Erbil to Altun Kopri Road sub-project, which will attract international contractors, components have been defined in an effort to allow local and regional contractors to fully participate in implementation.
Applying Lessons Learned
23. The quality of sectoral analyses underpinning projects i s important. For emergency operations, hasty needs assessments are often the only basis on which early Bank interventions arejustified. Inmany instances, these operations then suffer subsequent delays, must be restructured, or have their implementation periods extended to achieve a reasonable set o f objectives. For the proposed ERRP, an international consulting finn with a local counterpart carried out a detailed assessment o f the Iraqi transport sector over a one-year period, and this has served as a reliable instrument for structuring the ERRP.

- 5 -  24. Early assessnients persistently overstate the absorptive capacity o f post-conflict administrations. The inclination is to give benefit o f the doubt under such circumstances. Research indicates," however, that during the first few post-conflict years, absorptive capacity for aid is n o greater than normal, and typically well below expectations. The project will try to address this by keeping the structure simple, and involving consultants to assist ministries at all stages o f the project cycle (design, tender documents, bidding-award, and construction supervision).
25. Needs assessments sometimes lack ownership by new administrations. When this is the case, they should be revalidated to ensure priorities are aligned with emerging changes o n the ground, and associated costs revisited to ensure accuracy. Each o f the investments proposed in the ERRP were identified by counterparts, and subjected to the same selection criteria to help ensure quick and effective implementation. This has provided a better foundation for agreement o n priorities and possible project components.
26. The effectiveness of aid depends o n sector policies and institutions, the better the policies the larger the potential for growth. Project designs should reflect this and integrate policy advice and institutional assessments (and training), something which is reflected in the proposed project. The E W has sought to strike a carefLil balance between works and results o n the ground, and essential policy advice that will add value without generating resistance from beneficiaries.
27. Donors often bypass weak government capacity by contracting out services directly and providing assistance in kind. Bypassing local institutions is usually more expensive and can build resentment when aid money allocated to the country is used to fund firms from donor countries, international agencies and non-governmental organizations (NGOs), particularly when they have not been selected through competitive or transparent processes. The strategy for the ERRP will be to begin building capacity early on during implementation, while addressing short-term needs through temporary an-angements. This approach should enable a quick start to reconstruction activities and disbursements.
28. Recent experience in Iraq has highlighted the importance of professional due diligence o n projects prepared by Iraqi professionals. Moreover, considering the rise incost o f doing business inIraq, and the need for more accurate estimations of total project costs and realistic price contingencies, comprehensive feasibility studies during project preparation are highly advantageous. To prevent delays in implementation, consideration should be given to sequencing straight forward sub-projects for early implementation, and allowing additional time to prepare more complex operations. The ERRP will einploy this approach by initially utilizing SCRB designs for simple road improvements, and bringingin the services of engineering firms to prepare the ERRP's more challenging investments shortly after project launch.
29. Experience has also shown that it is difficult to predict project costs in areas where prices are affected by security risks, difficult mobilization, mine clearance actions, and supply/demand imbalances. This is especially true for materials that are subsidized (for instance, fuel and bitumen), or when supplies are subject to disruption. A flexible design i s needed that allows for a project's scope to be reviewed as part of an Early Implementation Assessment (after about 12 months), when contracting rates and other costs and implementation difficulties are better lmown.
30. Focusing on implementation arrangements during preparation i s important. The Project Management Team (PMT) model utilized in previous projects has proven to be quite effective, and apparently, other donors are considering using the same approach. Under this model, staff i s seconded, on a full-time and/or part-time basis, from various departments within the implementing ministry and its agencies to work in dedicated PMTs, which receive support from outside consultants. 25. Any excavated cut or unsuitable material shall be disposed of in designated tipping areas as agreed to by the Engineer.
26. Tips should not be located where they can cause fLiture slides, interfere with agricultural land or any other properties, or cause soil from the dump to be washed into any watercourse. Drains may need to be dug within and around the tips, as directed by the Engineer.
-82 -  Historical and Archeological Sites 27. If the Contractor discovers archeological sites, historical sites, remains and objects, including graveyards and/or individual graves during excavation or construction, the Contractor shall: (a) Stop the construction activities inthe area o f the chance find; (b) Delineate the discovered site or area; (c) Secure the site to prevent any damage or loss o f removable objects. In cases o f removable antiquities or sensitive remains, a night guard shall be present until the responsible local authorities and the Ministryof Culture take over; (d) Notify the supervisory Engineer who in turn will notify the responsible local authorities and the Ministry o f Cultureimmediately (less than 24 hours); (e) Contact the responsible local authorities and the Ministry o f Culture who will be in charge of protecting and preserving the site before deciding on the proper procedures to be carried out. This will require a preliminary evaluation of the findings to be performed by the archeologists o f the Ministry o f Culture (within 72 hours). The significance and importance o f the findings should be assessed according to the various criteria relevant to cultural heritage, including the aesthetic, historic, scientific or research, social and econoniic values; (f) Ensure that decisions on how to handle the findingbetaken by the responsible authorities and the Ministry o f Culture. This could include changes inthe layout (such as when the finding i s an irremovable remain o f cultural or archeological importance) conservation, preservation, restoration and salvage; (g) Implementation for the authority decision concerning the management of the finding shall be communicated in writing by the Ministry o f Culhire; and (h) Construction work will resume only after authorization is given by the responsible local authorities and the Ministry o f Culture concerning the safeguard o f the heritage.
Disposalof Construction and Vehicle Waste 28. Debris generated due to the dismantling o f the existing structures shall be suitably reused, to the extent feasible, in the proposed construction (e.g. as fill materials for embankments). The disposal o f remaining debris shall be carried out only at sites identified and approved by the project engineer. The contractor should ensure that these sites (a) are not located within designated forest areas; (b) do not impact natural drainage courses; and (c) do not impact endangeredrare flora. Under no circumstances shall the contractor dispose o f any material in environmentally sensitive areas.
29. In the event any debris or silt fioin the sites is deposited on adjacent land, the Contractor shall immediately remove such, debris or silt and restore the affected area to its original state to the satisfaction of the Supervisor/Engineer.
30. Bentonite slurry or similar debris generated from pile driving or other construction activities shall be disposed of to avoid overflow into the surface water bodies or fonn mudpuddles inthe area.
31. All arrangements for transportation during construction including provision, maintenance, dismantling and clearing debris, where necessary, will be considered incidental to the work and should be planned and implemented by the contractor as approved and directed by the Engineer.
32. Vehicle/machinery and equipment operations, maintenance and refueling shall be camed out to avoid spillage o f fiiels and lubricants and ground contamination. An 'oil interceptor" will be provided for wash down and refueling areas. Fuelstorage shall be located inproperbonded areas.
33. All spills and collected petroleum products shall be disposed o f in accordance with standard environmental procedures/guidelines. Fuel storage and refilling areas shall be located at least 300 meters from all cross drainage stnictures and important water bodies or as directed by the Engineer.

doc.abstracts: The objective of the Emergency Road Rehabilitation Project for Iraq is to improve the condition of road assets by rehabilitating highly damaged segments of the country's highway and rural road networks, reestablishing critical river crossings, and restoring the capacity to manage and maintain road assets. Part A (US$90.0 million) will provide financing to the central and southern Governorates to rehabilitate about 300 km o f highways, reconstruct some 150 km of village access roads, replace about three floating bridges with permanent structures, and establish a road asset management system. Part B (US$45.0 million) will provide financing to the three northern Governorates to rehabilitate the main road from Erbil to Altun Kopri (38.5 km), reconstruct around 75 km of village access roads, and establish a road asset management system.
